unnormalised: The day started like any other at AIIMS Delhi. As I walked through the bustling corridors, I saw Dr. Sharma, Head of Cardiology, deeply engrossed in a patient's file. Heâ€™s known for his dedication; often working late into the night. He greeted me with a warm smile, "Namaste! Another busy day, eh?"
normalised: The day started like any other at A-I-I-M-S Delhi. As I walked through the bustling corridors, I saw Doctor Sharma, Head of Cardiology, deeply engrossed in a patient's file. He's known for his dedication; often working late into the night. He greeted me with a warm smile, "Namaste! Another busy day, eh?"

unnormalised: Later, I spotted Dr. Kapoor, a renowned neurosurgeon, rushing towards the operating theatre. Apparently, there was an emergency case involving a patient from Patna. "Gotta run!" he called out, adjusting his surgical mask. "Let's catch up after I'm done. Should be around 6 PM." The pressure on these individuals is immense.
normalised: Later, I spotted Doctor Kapoor, a renowned neurosurgeon, rushing towards the operating theatre. Apparently, there was an emergency case involving a patient from Patna. "Gotta run!" he called out, adjusting his surgical mask. "Let's catch up after I'm done. Should be around six P-M." The pressure on these individuals is immense.

unnormalised: During my lunch break, I joined a group of nurses discussing the new guidelines issued by the Medical Council of India. They were debating the implications for their practice, especially regarding record-keeping. Sister Mary, the senior-most nurse in the department, shared her experiences of working in the hospital for over 30 years. "Things have changed so much since I joined! Back then, we didn't have all these Dr. this and Dr. that titles. We just respected everyone for their work."
normalised: During my lunch break, I joined a group of nurses discussing the new guidelines issued by the Medical Council of India. They were debating the implications for their practice, especially regarding record-keeping. Sister Mary, the senior-most nurse in the department, shared her experiences of working in the hospital for over thirty years. "Things have changed so much since I joined! Back then, we didn't have all these Doctor this and Doctor that titles. We just respected everyone for their work."

unnormalised: I also overheard a conversation between two interns, Mr. Verma and Ms. Reddy, about their upcoming exams. They were nervously quizzing each other on medical terminology. "What's the difference between a physician and a surgeon?" Mr. Verma asked, scratching his head. Ms. Reddy chuckled, "Seriously? Go back to your textbook, buddy!" They have to remember thousands of terms and titles and procedures.
normalised: I also overheard a conversation between two interns, Mister Verma and Miss Reddy, about their upcoming exams. They were nervously quizzing each other on medical terminology. "What's the difference between a physician and a surgeon?" Mister Verma asked, scratching his head. Miss Reddy chuckled, "Seriously? Go back to your textbook, buddy!" They have to remember thousands of terms and titles and procedures.

unnormalised: As the sun began to set, casting long shadows across the hospital grounds, I reflected on the diverse group of medical professionals I had encountered throughout the day. From the seasoned Prof. Khan, a specialist in infectious diseases, to the enthusiastic junior residents, each played a vital role in the hospital's mission to provide care and healing. Each one, from ward boy to Dr. Head of Department contributes so much.
normalised: As the sun began to set, casting long shadows across the hospital grounds, I reflected on the diverse group of medical professionals I had encountered throughout the day. From the seasoned Professor Khan, a specialist in infectious diseases, to the enthusiastic junior residents, each played a vital role in the hospital's mission to provide care and healing. Each one, from ward boy to Doctor Head of Department contributes so much.
